awd_titl_txt: RCN-SEES: Predictive Modeling Network for Sustainable Human-Building Ecosystems (SHBE)
awd_abstract_narration: 1338851 (Tao). The objective of this RCN is to develop a collaborative research platform centered on overcoming bottlenecks in engineering, software and social/economic sciences that impede wider application of sustainable building technology. The network activities will focus on defining an innovative, new interdisciplinary area, "Sustainable Human-Building Ecosystem (SHBE)," that integrates human behavioral science, social and economic sciences in tandem with sciences of building design, engineering, and metrology for data validation of building energy consumption and occupant comforts. The developed collaboration strategies and standardized data platform will lead to significant reductions of the uncertainty in predicting human adaptation to energy efficiency and sustainability of building ecosystems, which will also address fundamental questions such as "what are the benefits of sustainable building investment to people at a personal, business, or urban planning level?" The activities of the new SHBE-RCN include: collectively develop a consensus-based mechanism for an IT-enabled, data-networked research platform that allows sharing the connectivity methods from different models of building ecosystem elements; create the networking mechanism to recruit additional participants or update the working groups; develop the new research directions for identified subareas; evaluate the success of the SHBE network; and develop an innovative learning program for graduate students of diverse backgrounds. The steering committee members are from engineering, architecture, computer science, construction, environmental science, business and social science with national and international collaboration experience and access to data from various sustainable building projects: Yong Tao, Derrick D?Souza, and Ruthanne Thompson of the University of North Texas, William Tolone and Mirsad Hadzikadic of the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, David Cartes and Richard Feiock of Florida State University, Yimin Zhu and Thomas Spiegelhalter, of Florida International University, Wei Yan of Texas A&M University, Kee Poh Lam of Carnegie Mellon University, and Carol Menassa of the University of Wisconsin-Madison. The SHBE RCN aims to foster a new understanding of the complex interactions among the key elements of human-building ecosystems and to work towards a set of new theories for integration of predictive models to explore the following hypothesis: Integrating occupant behaviors with built environment performances validated from large field data sets can lead to significant reductions of the uncertainty in predictive models for human adaptation to energy efficiency and sustainability of building ecosystems. It will bring together researchers from different fields, who otherwise would not be able to network together, to form working groups focusing on understanding the interoperability (or inputs and outputs) of predictive models from different disciplines within the five thematic frameworks: I-Building physical system and environment modeling; II-Human behavior modeling; III-Social/policy impact modeling; IV-Dynamic life cycle assessment (LCA) and business ecosystem modeling; and V-Model integration and validation. All five themes are linked in such a way that no single theme will produce meaningful outcomes  without the significant input from other themes. This network?s research agenda will allow researchers to work towards solutions impacting people, their communities, and future of their lives. Providing a viable platform for meaningful research collaboration in quantifying the sustainable building ecosystem will enable the development of new theories and methods that could help city planners and political and financial decision makers to develop the most balanced sustainable solutions for both human and natural environment. The network management team will also implement a mechanism to promote diversity by recruiting graduate assistants and network participants through workshops and lab visits. This will be achieved by working with the Center for Diversity in Engineering and Computing at Florida International University, a Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI), and similar initiatives in the participating institutions. The network participants will also contribute to the development of a unique interdisciplinary learning program, based on the concept of an outcome-driven, diverse, and individualized learning mechanism.

Addressing the objectives of this project, the SHBE-RCN has achieved the following outcomes:

Interdisciplinary Research Collaborations and Impacts.  SHBE project activities and networking events promoted effective collaboration among participating researchers and developed new research directions. Every year, numerous projects are inspired by the SHBE networking activities.  During the 2020-2022 period, the following projects have been completed or continuing:

- Developing a long-term, sustainable platform that enables researchers from multiple disciplines to continuously engage in active collaborations under a broader umbrella of Wellbeing-Centric Human-Building Ecosystems (see the attached visuals) by employing Big Data Analytics Research, inspired by the NSF RCN-SEES vision, and identified from several SHBE-RCN workshops.  Those disciplines include architecture, various engineering (civil, architectural, mechanical, and electrical engineering), computer science, and social science.

- Establishing a Virtual Information-Fabric Infrastructure (VIFI) for Data-Driven Decisions from Distributed Data.  This Project aids the decision  new foundational and transformative infrastructure solutions for data-driven discovery without compromised data sources.

- Supporting earlier career researchers in research networking activities and engaging graduate students in International Research Experience and Professional Development in Built Environment Sustainability.

- Integrating research with curricular development for energy education, and

- Many research projects inspired by SHBE-RCN?s networking activities, funded by NSF, DOE and other funding agencies.

Participation in the SHBE workshops has made an impact on many attendees regarding their research agenda or scholarly work. Respondents from the COVID-19 and built environment workshop indicated that they had a better understanding how the COVID-19 has broad impacts on building operation, energy use, and occupant health. Participants from both workshops also reported that they found the discussion sessions very helpful to formulate future research ideas and understand possible funding sources to support the ideas.

Information Dissemination.  The SHBE team launched a new SHBE-RCN website by the 2019/20 academic year as an interdisciplinary research platform to promote sustainable building technology. This website offered resources for different research topics, recruited participants for workshops or webinars, promoted project products, and provided collaboration and networking opportunities for researchers.

- The project team also made strong efforts to disseminate findings from research projects inspired by the network. They shared findings as conference and workshop presentation, conference proceedings and journal articles.

- A major challenge to the SHBE network was the COVID-19 pandemic. Due to COVID, during the 2020-2022 evaluation period, in person meetings, workshops, evaluation activities, and related travelling were postponed, which imposed a challenge to the networking efforts of this project. The project tried to overcome this through virtual workshops and team meetings.

Networking Effectiveness. The project was successful in creating the networking mechanism to recruit participants for workshops. Workshops were promoted through multiple channels, such as a call-for-participation flier posted on the SHBE-RCN website and via email invitations sent to the community of interest two month prior to the workshop. The call-for-participation flier summarized the goal of a workshop and set expectations by describing topics to be discussed in the workshop.

Overall, participants had a positive perspective of a workshop regarding its organization and quality. A unanimous high rating shows that participants agreed to strongly agreed that the workshops were well planned, presenters were well prepared, and workshop organizers and presenters were helpful answering questions and leading/facilitating discussions.

- The project shows the strong collaboration between the project leaders in the Steering Committee; and diverse backgrounds of project leadership and their shared interested in sustainable building. The close connection and collaborations that project leadership has built with each other was the key to the success of the SHBE network.

- The research team has demonstrated a strong orientation toward sustainability of the SHBE project. The leadership has sought ways to sustain and extend the partnerships they have put into place nationally and internationally, such as promoting the project through multiple channels, enhancing the collaborative research activities by recruiting new members and inspiring new research directions, and creating a strong network between the project and the community of interest.

Overall, about 280 participants attended three international workshops, 12 US workshops, a number of meetings and other networking events organized by SHBE-RCN, including 20 US universities, and 13 International universities and 5 industrial and national lab units.  More than 65 graduate students are engaged as well.  Collectively, the SHBE-RCN participants have contributed more than 155 technical publications, including 109 journal papers, 4 books or book chapters, and 42 conference papers, to the literature inspired by and related to SHBE-RCN activities, and made more than 29 presentations in invited talks, panels and exhibitions.
